While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting corn for sale. Wilfredo has been engaged in his business for over 16 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Wilfredo joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wilfredo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Wilfredo is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Wilfredo from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Luk

texts.en: Luk N., 41, is married and lives with two of her children in the Siem Reap province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about US$5 each day. They also often purchase a stock of rice to resell to wholesalers at the market for an additional profit to raise their standard of living. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. Luk N. is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase rice in bulk to get a special discount. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: Buy and sell rice.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther J. is currently in the business of selling fish and is requesting a loan to stock more dried fish to sell. Esther is 47 years old and is married to a policeman. She has six children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more dried fish to sell

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Bun C., 48, is married with two children. He lives with his wife (pictured) in Battambong Province. He is engaged in a business selling groceries on boat at Tonle Sap Lake (the great lake of Cambodia) to people living on water. He is able to earn approximately an income US $6 per day in revenue. His wife is engaged in the agriculture sector of raising pigs at home, earning an income of US $3 per day. This couple is asking for a loan of US $1200 to purchase more various kinds of groceries to expand the husband’s business. Also, she plans to purchase more rice to manufacture rice wine and to make the waste from rice wine producing as food for the pigs she is raising. She hopes that her business plan will be successful, and her family standard of living will be improved.

loans.use: buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 24-year-old man who lives with his wife in Bourj El Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon.

Ali owns a shop and he works as a car electrician. He needs a loan from Al Majmoua in order to expand his business by purchasing merchandise. This is the third time that Ali has requested a loan.

Ali is special in his work because he works on both mechanical and electrical problems for cars. His clients are his friends, neighbors and people from his region. In the future, he plans on expanding his work and opening a bigger shop.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for his store

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena is a 47-year-old business woman who resides in the village of San Vicente, Quirino, Isabela. Her husband, who is now 49 years old, is busy cultivating their farm lot in their village. They have nine children: some are married and some are still studying. As a mother, she hopes to give the best to her children as much as possible.

Elena is hoping to borrow PHP 4,000 as additional capital for her hog-raising business. She is planning to buy more hogs so that she will have more income after selling them. To uplift their poor way of living is her ambition in life and, with the help of Kiva lenders, she hopes to get started. She really prays for the approval of her loan.

loans.use: To buy more piglets to raise

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Huon

texts.en: Farming rice is part of 30-year-old Huon M.’s daily routine. Rice is a necessary product vital to Cambodian people. She learned to do this from her grandmother and she is very widely known in this sector since before she was married. Her husband, Svay Pheng, assists her with the farm work and he appears in the photograph. In addition, Huon M.’s husband also spends time on the river for a fishing activity. This couple lives with two children who attend school and also work on the farm. Huon M. will be using the loan to buy fertilizer and seed to facilitate rice-growing. With the remainder of loan she will buy a fishing tool to supply her husband business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seed to facilitate rice-growing

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Chan K., 26, is widowed and has a young child. She lives in Battambong Province with her sister and her child.

K. is engaged in a business sewing Cambodian traditional clothes, earning an income of US$5 per day. Her daily expenses do not allow her to save enough income to improve her business. Therefore, K. is asking for a loan of US$800 to purchase a new sewing machine that is reliable enough to handle heavy work in the business. By doing so, she hopes her current business will be improved, and she is able to generate more income for household use.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: John's Group

texts.en:
L. John is a 41-year-old hardworking man who is married with nine children aged 18 years to 4 months. He also takes care of other orphans.

John has been a mechanic in Nantabulirwa for 11 years and he is able to make 100,000/= in weekly profits. He makes metal doors, windows and gates and his biggest business challenge is having to use expensive metals to ensure that he makes quality products to win more customers in order to be able to educate his children.

John needs to secure a loan to be able to boost his business by buying more metal to be used in his business for increased profitability.

loans.use: To buy more metal for his business

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 34 year old man who lives in Bourj El Barajneh, southern suburbs of Lebanon with his wife and their three children. Ahmad has owned a mini market for two years. He sells most kind of juices, biscuits, and other merchandises. He requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase more goods for his mini market. This is his first cycle and he has always paid on time. 
His clients are his friends and people in the region. Ahmad decided on doing his business and in the future, he plans on expanding his work.

loans.use: To urchase more goods for his mini market.

loans.name: Imoi

texts.en: Imoi S. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol and is requesting a loan to purchase more brewing materials. Imoi is 40 years old and is married to a security guard. She has six children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a bigger bar for selling beer, wines, etc. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more brewing materials

loans.name: Teresa De Jesús

texts.es: Teresa D. Jesús M. D. P. resiD. en Sensutepeque en el departamento D. Cabañas. Teresa  vive solamente con sus cuatro hijos, ya que su esposo se encuentra trabajando fuera del país. Teresa extraña mucho la unión D. su familia y es por eso que se esmera mucho en su negocio para que su esposo regrese al hogar que lo espera. Teresa tiene una tienda D. productos D. consumo, la cual quiere surtir por medio D. este crédito.

loans.use: Surtir su negocio

loans.name: Bodildo

texts.en:
Bodildo H. is 46 years old and lives with his wife and five children in Hovd province in western Mongolia. He and his family all live together in a small house. His two oldest children currently attend university, his middle two children are secondary school students, and his youngest is in kindergarten. H. operates a clothing trading business in his town. To supplement his income, he rents out two rooms in his house to local college students. H. started his clothing business in 2004 and has since gained much experience in his trade. He attributes his success to the good reputation he has built with his customers. He is requesting a 2,500,000 tugrug loan to purchase fall and winter clothes to sell in the upcoming seasons.								

Bodildo's wife, who runs the clothing business with him, is pictured above.

loans.use: To purchase fall and winter clothes to sell

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles O. was a security guard at one of the security firms based in Nairobi, Kenya. As he advanced into old age, he opted to retire and concentrate more on farming as a business in his rural area back in Nambale, Busia District. As nature dictates, he buys his stock of seed twice a year due to the two rainy seasons. He is married with twelve children and plans to use the loan to buy more seed and expand his farm since he already has available stock and the rains are just round the corner. He says food business is the best. There is always someone willing to buy food fresh from the farm. Charles O. requires a loan of Kshs. 10,000.

loans.use: Buy seeds and expand his farming area.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Vevencia

texts.en:
Vevencia Sta. R. is from the village of Liloan-Bonifacio Mis. Occ. She is 54 years old. Vevencia is married and has one adult child. To make a living, Vevencia owns & operates a retail store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Vevencia has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Vevencia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vevencia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Vevencia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units with offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Venancia

texts.en:
Venancia G. is from the village of Bocator Tangub City. She is 57 years old. Venancia is married and has one adult child. To make a living, Venancia owns & operates a fishing business selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Venancia has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Venancia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Venancia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Venancia is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Venancia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units with offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mil

texts.en: The 75 % of Cambodia people who has been growing a rice crop, because they thinks that the rice is a necessary product vital for their life. One of these people, Mrs. Mil K., age 57, who is very widely known in this sector since before she was married. Mil K. is married with eight children: four are married and the remainders are single. Most of them are employed in different jobs. Her husband, Sharoeun, 59, assists her with the farm work. Mil K. is taking out her first loan to buy more fertilizers to fatten her crop yield and the rest of the loan she will buy a bicycle to ride to her farm field.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers to fatten her crop yield and the rest of the loan she will buy a bicycle to ride to her farm field

loans.name: Hamida Row Havza Group

texts.en:
Hamida Row Havza is the group leader of Hamida Row Havza group. There are seven members in this group. They want to take a loan for expanding their business and making them larger.

Hamida wants to take a loan for the business of tailoring. Rabi wants to take a loan for the business of flower making. Row Havza wants to take a loan for her husband who has car parts shop. Nargis wants to take a loan for the business of bead working.

Rakia wants to take a loan for the business of quilt making. Deba wants to take a loan for the business of embroidery. Maliha wants to receive a loan for the business of carpet weaving. They all thank AFS and Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For business progress

loans.name: Juliet's Group

texts.en: M. Juliet is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is a hard working and friendly lady with a business of selling timber and charcoal from the Industrial area for 6 years where she is even able to make 120,000/= as profits a week. Juliet’s business is mostly affected with high transportation costs plus the forestry officials that demand a lot of taxes hence cutting on her profits. She hopes to expand her business to have more kinds of timber for construction so as o increase income as well as to be able to pay school fees for her children and feeding. Juliet is married with 9 children as she takes care of 2 orphans and her sick mother and she would like a loan to help buy more timber for resale.

loans.use: Juliet would like to buy more timber and charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Cecelia

texts.en:
Cecelia O. the one in front wearing red t-shirt is from the village of Panalsalan Plaridel Misamis Occidental. She is 46 years old. Cecelia is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Cecelia owns & operates a fishing business selling seafood products such as fish, shells "kinason" and etc. to local community members. Cecelia has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Cecelia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cecelia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC. Cecelia is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP' which will be used to purchase additional seafood products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Cecelia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seafood to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more timbers

loans.name: Benta

texts.en: Benta A. is a jovial mother who has been blessed with five children. She is very enthusiastic about how she manages to take care of her children. This, she says, is because she has been able to take care of them as the family breadwinner. She says it has not been easy since she lost her husband, but the joy of struggling in life gives her the zeal to keep going.  To earn a living, she sells fresh farm produce at the market and the surrounding homes in the village. She will be using half of the loan as extra capital to sustain her business growth. The rest will go to extension and preparation of the farms. She requires a loan of Kshs. 10,000.

loans.use: As extra capital and farm preparation

loans.name: Sopia

texts.en:
Sopia E. is from the village of Bocator Tangub City. She is 60 years old. Sopia is married and has one adult child. To make a living, Sopia owns & operates an "alimango" (mud crab) fishing business selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Sopia has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Sopia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sopia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell and to expand the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Sopia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units with offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell and invest to expand the business

loans.name: Kroch

texts.en: Kroch B., 57, is engaged in the business of sewing and designing clothes at her home, earning an income of US $4 per day. She is married with five children. One of her children is pictured at her workplace because B. was not available. She lives with her husband in Kompong Chnang Province. Her husband works for the government in the town, earning an income of US $3 per day. The family is also assisted by three of the children who are currently employed in a local garment factory. B. is seeking to improve her standard of living, so she has requested a loan of US $700 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to use to commute to work. She hopes that her new motorbike will enable her family to cut back on public transportation expenses.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband

loans.name: Erina's Group

texts.en: N. Erina is a determined and friendly lady with three children ages 12, 7 & 4 years. She also helps to take care of other orphans. Erina has had a business selling charcoal from Namataba trading centre for 11 years and she is able to make 70,000/= as profit because she uses loans and has good customer care skills. In Namataba, almost everyone sells charcoal and one needs to be good and have good quality charcoal to be able to make enough sales. She has hopes of becoming a supplier of charcoal herself so that she could be able to earn at once and be able to build a residential house for her children. She needs a loan to be able to buy more sacks of charcoal so that she can have a steady supply and pay school fees on time.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more crops in bulk

loans.name: Ana Gladis

texts.es: Ana Gladis A. V. reside en Candelaria en el departamento de Cuscatlán.  Ana tiene tan solo 20 años de edad, vive con su familia padre y madre. A pesar de ser muy joven Ana siempre ha ayudado a su familia en los negocios, ahora Ana se dedica a la elaboración de puros los que realiza desde su casa, el crédito que solicita es para compra materiales que se utilizan para la elaboración de puros.
texts.en:
Ana Gladis A. V. lives in Candelaria in the Cuscatlán department. Ana is only 20, and she lives with her mother and father. In spite of being very young, Ana has always helped her family in their business. Ana makes cigars in her house. The loan she is asking for is to buy materials to make cigars.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy raw material

loans.name: Alba Arely

texts.es: Alba Arely I. A. reside en San Juan Opico en el departamento de La Libertad. Alba de 34 años de edad vive con su esposo y sus dos hijos Nelson de 6 anos y Edwin de 2 años. Alba  tiene una tienda ubicada en su casa la cual instalo pensado que era una buena y provechosa manera de  trabajar y a su vez cuidar de sus hijos, en la tiende de Alba se vende variedad de productos para el hogar,  Alba es un persona muy responsable ha manejado dos créditos anteriormente los cuales ha cancelado y fue muy puntual en sus pagos, este nuevo crédito que solicita es para surtir su negocio.
texts.en:
Alba Arely I. A. lives in San Juan Opico in the La Libertad department. Alba, 34, lives with her husband and their two children. Nelson is six, and Edwin is two. Alba has a store, which is located in her house. She set it up thinking that it would be a good and beneficial way to work and take care of her children at the same time. In the store Alba sells a variety of products for the home. Alba is a very responsible person. She has managed two previous loans, which she repaid by making her payments punctually. The new loan she is asking for is to stock her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her business

loans.name: Chanhorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanhorn S., 26 and her husband, Mr. Norn Nor, 27, live on an island on the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married since 2004 and just have one young son. 

Chanhorn has been a silk weaver since she was 16 years old. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village where she lives, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market. Her husband is a farmer. 

Chanhorn hopes to continue her business because it’s the main business to earn income for supporting her family. So, she is requesting a loan of $200 to purchase silk materials for operating her business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for continuing her silk weaving business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk for  her business

loans.name: Claudia Georgina

texts.es: Claudia Georgina L. C. de 34 años de edad reside en el departamento de Ahuachapán vive con su esposo y sus tres hijos. Claudia ha sabido explotar sus habilidades, ella se destaca mucho en la cocina y es así como se lanza a poner su propio comedor el cual ahora es el favorito de muchos, que degustan de los platillos hechos en el comedor de Claudia, ahora ella solita de un crédito para comprar mayor cantidad de insumos para la producción de su platillos.

loans.use: compra de materia prima

loans.name: Ana Del Carmen

texts.es: Ana Del Carmen G. D. P. resiD. en el departamento D. Ahuachapán junto a su esposo y sus tres hijos dos ya mayores D. edad y una niña D. 9 años que se encuentra estudiando. Ana tiene su negocio el cual le permite generar ingresos que son D. gran ayuda para los gastos D. la familia, El negocio D. Ana es una tienda muy pequeña, la cual atreves D. este crédito piensa surtir, ya que le hace falta muchos productos que sus clientes le demandan, es por ello que solicita D. un crédito para surtir su negocio que le ayudará a incrementar sus ventas.
texts.en:
Ana Del Carmen G. D. P. lives in Ahuachapán with her husband, their three older sons and their nine year old daughter who is a student. Ana has her business which allows her to earn income that is a great help with the family expenses. Ana's business is a very small store which she plans to stock through this loan since she is missing many products her clients ask her for. Because of this she requests a credit in order to supply her business which will help her increase her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her business

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 27 years old Juliana S.  from Mbozi. She is married  with 4  children, between the ages of 7 and 20. Juliana Shas been running a crops  business since 2007. Client’s business is purchasing and selling crops . She works at the business for 9-12  hours per day, 6 days per week Juliana currently earns about 200 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase crops in bulk for business . In the future, she plans to open the same business at new location . Juliana thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk

loans.name: Filda's Group

texts.en:
Y. Filda, 28 years old, is married and has four children between the ages of three and 13. She also helps to take care of her parents in the village.

For six years, Filda has run a business selling high-quality clothes and cosmetics in Buikwe. From this work, she is able to make about 80,000 UGX a week in profits. Before she began to receive loans, Filda sold only cosmetics, but now she also sells clothes because she has the capital to do so. This in addition to her friendly disposition has won her many customers and hence more profits. She has a dream of becoming a wholesaler as well as building a residential house for her children.

At the moment, Filda needs a loan to be able to add more capital to her business, since she used some of the money from the business to pay her children’s school fees.

loans.use: Buying more clothes for resale in her business.

loans.name: Hermina

texts.en:
Hermina believes that investment is compared to a treasure that is quite useful when you are badly in need. She is happily married and generally has nine adult-aged children. With her investment in business, she is hoping to help her children in time of their needs. Hermina and her husband lives together in the village of La Salette, Benito Soliven, Isabela.
	Hermina is involved in raising of hogs in their village. She has two hogs so far and she is still hoping to increase their numbers when her loan amounting to PHP4,000 will be granted. She also hopes to have supply of feeds so that she won’t encounter any problem anymore in times of shortage. She aims to uplift their living condition someday with the help of her husband, lenders and most especially with our merciful God.

loans.use: additional capital to buy more pigs and feeds

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk

loans.name: Gloria Milena

texts.es: Gloria Milena A. D. T. resiD. en el departamento D. Ahuachapán. Con tan solo 24 años D. edad Gloria ya es madre D. su primogénito llamado Walter D. 5 años D. edad, el esposo D. Gloria vive con ella y trabaja. Gloria muy consciente D. la difícil situación económica ha decido trabajar; y es así como atienD. D. su negocio en el mercado municipal D. Ahuachapán, donD. venD. variedad D. medicina popular, es decir sin necesidad D. prescripción médica, el crédito que solicita Gloria es para surtir su negocio.
texts.en:
Gloria Milena A. D. T. lives in the Ahuachapán department. Gloria is only 24, and she has a five year old son, Walter. Gloria’s husband lives with her, and he works. Gloria is very well aware of the difficult economic situation, and she has decided to work. That is why she works at her business in the Ahuachapán municipal market. She sells a variety of popular medicines. That is to say, over the counter medicine. The loan that Gloria is asking for is to stock her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her inventory

loans.name: Firida

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 34  years old Firida  S.  from Mbozi . She is married  with 6  children, between the ages of 10 and 18 . Firida has been running a clothes  business since 2002 . Client’s business is purchasing  and selling clothes. She works at the business for 9-12  hours per day, 6  days per week a. Firida currently earns about 250 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase more clothes in bulk  for  her business. In the future, she plans to open the same business at new location . Firida thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes in bulk

loans.name: Sarith

texts.en:
Mr. Sarith R., age 45 and his wife, Leangse Neng, age 43, were married in 1990 and have three children: one son and two daughters. All of them are in school. The family lives in a small village about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. Sarith’s wife is shown in the photo.

Sarith has been driving a motor taxi since 1989 while his wife stays at home to take care of their son. He is requesting his first loan of 500 USD to build a fence around his house.

loans.use: To build a fence around his house

loans.name: Makau

texts.en: Makau M. is a 53-year-old widow from Nambale, Busia District, in Kenya.  She has eight children. Makau sells both fresh and fried fish as a way of generating income for her big family. She has been involved in this business since 1984 (25 years). Makau says she restocks twice a week. She needs a loan of Ksh 20,000, which she says she will use to buy more fish and expand her business. She wants to secure her children's further education, both currently and in the future.

loans.use: Buy more fish stock and expand business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
Ofelia has been engaged in managing her general store business for ten years. She wants to grow her business and be more profitable for the welfare of her three children. Ofelia is requesting a loan amounting to PHP25,000 so that she will have additional revolving capital for the expansion of her business. She wants to buy more products to sell in order to meet her customers' demands. She hopes to be given the chance to further improve her business.

Ofelia is now 36 years old and is married to Wilfredo who works as a farmer in their village. They are blessed with three children who are all in school. Their eldest, Teffany Joy, is a third-year high school student. Their second child, John Mark, is 12 years old and currently a first-year high school student. Their youngest, Wilfredo, is 9 years old and in fourth grade. With her business, she hopes to assist her children in attaining their dreams. As she stated, "If you do, you'll win; if you don't, you won't."

loans.use: additional revolving capital to buy more products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase stationery supplies

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 53-year-old Joyce K. from Mbozi  She is married and has five children between the ages of 12 and 24. Joyce has been running a crops business since 2005. She purchases and sells crops. She works at her business for 9-12 hours a day, 6 days a week. Joyce currently earns about $100 a month from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase crops in bulk. In the future, she plans to improve the quality and range of the crops she sells. Joyce thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk

loans.name: Girlie

texts.en:
Girlie C., who is 39 years old, has been in the furniture business for four years.  She manages her own furniture shop.  Through the years, she has increased her business and was able to open a branch in Pasig City.  She earns a monthly net income of about $185.  She uses her profits to purchase raw materials for making furniture.  Part of her earnings goes to her children’s education.

Girlie hails from the province of Pampanga, but has decided to migrate to Bagong Silang, Caloocan City.  Her husband, Edwin, works at a restaurant.  Their four children are all in school, at different levels. 

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in the last quarter of 2007.  She has diligently paid back her previous loan from the cooperative and has applied for a new loan in the amount of P14,000, which she will use to purchase raw materials (wood, nails, wood adhesives, lacquer and tools for furniture making).  

She looks forward to supplying furniture items to large stores and showrooms in the city, and to employing the services of many craftsmen in their community.



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for making furniture.

loans.name: María Candelaria

texts.es: María Candelaria M. D. D. C. resiD. en el oriente D. país en San Francisco Gotera D. departamento D. Morazán. María vive con su hijo quien estudia y su esposo que le ayuda en el negocio. María tiene un comedor donD. todos los días da servicio, se venden desayunos, almuerzos, tortillas y bebidas; el crédito que solita María es porque quiere comprar al por mayor,  ya que se ahorra mucho y esto le hará obtener mayor margen D. ganancias.
texts.en:
Maria lives in the eastern part of the country, in San Francisco Gotera, Morazan Department. She lives with her son who studies and her husband who helps her in the business.

Maria has an eatery where she offers her services every day. She sells breakfasts, lunches, tortillas and drinks. The loan Maria requests is to buy supplies at wholesale, since she can save a lot this way and obtain a greater profit margin.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY SUPPLIES AT WHOLESALE

loans.name: Iris Margarita

texts.es: Iris Margarita O. M. de 25 años de edad reside en El Refuguio del departamento de Ahuachapán. Iris vive con su madre, esposo y su hijo Elías de 3 años de edad. Iris tiene seis años de tener su negocio, una tienda con productos para el hogar y de consumo, ahora Iris ha expandido su negocio con la venta de cosméticos ya que son rápidamente vendidos, el crédito que hoy solita es por ello para surtir de cosméticos y otros productos para su negocio.

loans.use: Surtir su negocio

loans.name: Jamila's Group

texts.en:
(Jamila in the small photo; is also a part of the group although not in the group photo)
N. Jamila is a hard working and devoted lady with a business of selling nice plastics and sauce pans. She started 10 years ago selling plates, cups and saucepans and although there is a lot of competition, she is able to make 100,000/= a week from Buikwe trading centre. She is moving her path to success because of the loans, good customer care plus having quality products in her stock. Jamila has a dream of becoming a whole sale supplier plus educating all her children to the University level. She is married with 7 children aged 20 – 4 years and all in school as she takes care of her siblings. Jamila needs a loan to be able to add more capital into her business since most of the money she makes goes into school fees payments and food for home consumption.

loans.use: Buying more plastic cups, plates and sauce pans for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase shop items in bulk

loans.name: Baatarjav

texts.en: B. is 26 years old and lives with his wife and two year old daughter in the Khovd province of western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. B.’s wife is a teacher at a local school and his daughter attends kindergarten.  B. operates a taxi service between the Khovd province and Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He began his business in 2006 and has gained a lot of experience since then. Because the trip between Kovd and Ulaanbaatar takes approximately 30 hours and much of it is on unpaved roads, B.’s microbus is in constant need of upkeep and repair. He is planning on purchasing a new microbus when he can afford it, but for now, he is requesting a 2,500,000 tugrug (~1750 USD) loan to purchase parts for his current microbus.

loans.use: To purchase parts for his current microbus

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: acheter des engrais et effectuer des labours

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer J., 33, is in the bicycle rental business.  She hails from Bagong Silang, Caloocan City.  Her husband, Bonifacio, age 36, works at a nearby factory.  They have two children who both attend a pre-school.

Jennifer rents out bicycles to customers, both adults and children.  She has been in this business for four years.  She sometimes has trouble when a customer runs away with a bicycle or returns a broken bicycle to her shop. However, she still likes her work very much because she gets to know a lot of people from different walks of life.  She earns close to $93 a month in net income.  

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2007.  Now on her 7th loan cycle, Jennifer needs a loan of P14,000 for the continuity of her business.  She would buy spare parts for the repairs of her bicycles.   She is also helping her husband save for the renovation of their house.



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for her rental bicycles.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk for  her business

loans.name: Martina

texts.en: Three years ago Martina W. had a fish-selling business. She decided to venture into farm produce because she could run it from her home, unlike the fish business where she had to travel long distances to buy fish to sell. Martina is married and the mother of three children between the ages of 15 and 21. She plans to expand her farming area and to buy more seedlings and fertilizer. For this she needs a loan of Kshs.10,000.

loans.use: Buy seeds and expand farming.

loans.use: To purchase more shop items in bulk

loans.name: Emily  Wanjiru

texts.en:
Emily is married to G. and they have seven children: Elizabeth, Evans, George, James, Margaret, Esther and Peter.

Emily has been in the housing business for four years. She was introduced to KADET through existing clients and she has no previous credit history.

The area in which Emily operates is densely populated, thus she is able to attract a lot of customers. Emily will use the loan to renovate her rental houses and add untensils and furniture to her food kiosk. With the profits she earns as a result of the loan, she intends to add more rental houses. Her hopes are to purchase a kerosene pump and place it in a strategic place where she resides. Emily believes she is innovative and hardworking.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Emily will use the loan to renovate her rental houses and add untensils and furniture to her food kiosk.

loans.name: Pho

texts.en:
Pictured above are Mr. Pho B., age 34, and his wife, Mrs. Navy Touch, age 36. They were married in 1990 and have five children, two sons and three daughters, all of whom are in school. They live along National Road Number 6, about 25 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Mr. Pho B. has been selling recycling materials for four years. He buys it from his villagers for resale to a middleman who comes to buy it at his house. Mrs. Navy Touch stays at home to take care of their children.  

Pheap hopes to expand his business. It will be better if he can generate more income for supporting his family, because his business is their main source of income. He is asking for his first loan of $500 to purchase more recycling materials for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more recycling materials for resale.

loans.name: Edith Xiomara

texts.es: Edith Xiomara B. D. R. D. 31 años D. edad resiD. en Mejicanos municipio del departamento D. San Salvador. Edith vive con su esposo y sus dos hijos Jerson D. 8 años y Emilio D. un año D. edad. Edith recibe el apoyo económico D. su esposo quien trabaja como profesor, pero Edith lo apoya económicamente,  con su pequeño negocio, una librería que no tiene competencia alguna en la zona, Edith venD. variedad D. productos D. uso básico, pero ahora quiere surtir su negocio para ir expandiéndose  y obteniendo mayores ventas.
texts.en:
Edith Xiomara B. D. R., 31, lives in the Mejicanos municipality in the San Salvador department. Edith lives with her husband and their two children. Jerson is eight, and Emilio is one. Edith receives economic support from her husband who works as a teacher. Edith helps him economically with her small business. She has a bookstore, which has no competition in the region. Edith sells a variety of products for basic use. But, she now wants to stock her business to expand it and get greater sales.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her business

loans.name: Wilson Ongore

texts.en:
Wilson is married and has three children: Emmanuel, age 24, Gabriel, age 21, and Cynthia, age 16.

Wilson has been in the vegetable supply business for nine years. His other source of income is from rental houses. He intends to use his loan to purchase a chemical spray machine to help his vegetable supply business and to renovate his rental houses. He was introduced to KADET through an existing borrower group and he has no previous credit history.

Wilson's area of business is densely populated with low income earners, who are Wilson's customers. With the profits Wilson earns, he intends to pay school fees for his children.

Wilson hopes to own an estate in the future, and he describes himself as determined and focused.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase a chemical spray machine and to renovate rental houses.

loans.name: Josephine Akoth

texts.en:
Josephine is married to Samson and they have no children yet.

Josephine has been in the tailoring business for fourteen years. She was introduced to KADET through existing clients and she has no previous credit history. Josephine will use her loan to purchase additional fabric so that she can make more clothing and maximize her profits. 

The client's customers are mainly from the rural areas, and sees most of her customers on market days. With the extra profits she will develop a piece of land. Her hopes are to become a landlady. She believes she is hardworking.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Josephine will use her loan to purchase additional fabric so that she can make more clothing and maximize her profits

loans.name: Gunzen

texts.en:
A. is 38 years old and lives with her husband and six children, age 7 to 18, in the Hovd province of western Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, and all of her children attend a local secondary school.

A. operates a business where she sews traditional Mongolian clothes such as deels, or long coats. She began her business in 2000 and has since then become established in the local business community. A. sews a wide variety of deels which can be worn throughout the year. She hopes to become even more successful so that she can provide for her large family in the future.

A. is requesting a 150,000 tugrug loan so that she can purchase more fabric and items such as buttons and trim for her business.

loans.use: To buy more fabric and items such as buttons and trim

loans.name: Paul  Njenga

texts.en:
Paul is married to Jane and they have three children: Rachel, Irene and Callen.

Paul has been in the butchery business for six years. His other source of income is rental rooms. He was introduced to KADET through group members. Paul's business area is densely populated and his customers are residential clients. Paul will use his loan to open a new butchery within the market and to renovate his existing butchery shop.

With the extra profits, Paul intends to  pay school fees for his children. Paul's hopes are to expand the business and to become a wholesaler meat supplier as he believes he is focused, determined and hardworking.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Shs 60,000 will be used to open a new butchery within the market, shs 20,000 will be used to renovate his existing butchery shop.

loans.use: To purchase shop items in bulk

loans.name: Jacob Mukangai

texts.en:
Jacob is 38 years old, married and blessesd with five children. His agricultural business is located at Seregeya market in Eldoret. He was introduced to KADET by a friend.

With the loan Jacob receives from KADET, he intends to buy more sheep.In the future he aspires to excel in his business and be able to educate his children. One day, he hopes to be able to buy a plot of land for his family in order to better meet his family's basic needs.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more animals for his agricultural business

loans.name: Chuluundorj

texts.en:
Chuluundorj B. is 41 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Harhorin, the capital city of the ancient Mongolian empire. Both of his children, a son and daughter, attend a local secondary school. His wife works as a janitor at her children's school.

Chuluundorj manages a business in his town making wooden products. He is a very busy man, as he operates his wood business during the day and supplements his income by driving a taxi at night. B. started his wood-products business in 2000 and has since found much success in his trade. With his savings, he was able to purchase his car and start the taxi service in 2005.

B. has worked very hard at growing his business, but was forced to halt operations for three years to take care of his ailing father. However, today, he is working again and says, "My only wish now is to finish building my house, which will greatly improve my family's quality of life." He is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug loan to purchase more wood for his wood-products business.

loans.use: To buy more wood for his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy clothes in bulk

loans.name: Hezron

texts.en:
Hezron Harun A. is a former mason who retired back in 2001. His former work is most likely reflected in his strong-willed face. He is married with seven children who all depend on him for school fees.

Hezron retired from masonry and decided to concentrate on farming. First, it was for the family food production only but, as time went by, more needs arose. These needs needed money so he moved on to farming fresh farm produce which he has been doing since 2002.

Hezron requires a loan of Kshs 10,000 to expand his farming area and to buy more seedlings in time for the Christmas festivities. He also says he is proud of Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand his farming area and to buy seedlings

loans.name: 5 Sisters Empowerment Group

texts.en:
5 Sisters Empowerment is a group of 5 borrowers led by Musu M., 45 years old, married with 4 children aged 22-32 years old. Their educational levels are 12th grade-university graduate. Musu also cares for 2 orphans. She and her family live in Banjour, a newly built community for poor people who can't afford to buy town lots, north of the capital, Monrovia, Liberia.

Musu's business is selling charcoal. She buys charcoal wholesale and sells it retail to residents of Banjour, north of the capital, Monrovia, Liberia.
She has been running this business for 10 years and hoping to establish a transportation business in the future.

Musu talks to her customers in a good manner in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. She needs this loan in order to purchase new goods. Musu dreams of improving the living standard of herself and her family.

loans.use: to purchase new goods

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira B., 37 years old, started her general store six year ago. She lives with her three children and her husband, Armando, in a populous village in Tala, Caloocan City.

Elvira saves her profits to build up funds for the renovation of their house. Part of her earnings also goes to her children’s education. She is now making P 6,500 in net income per month.

She considers being a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative a blessing for her business and her family. Elvira is now in need of a new loan in the amount of P10,000 as additional capital for her general store. She will purchase grocery items and soft drinks.

Elvira wishes to help her children continue their education until college.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.name: Naumi

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 28 years old Naumi   M. from Mbeya.. Naumi has been running a timbers  business since 2008. Client’s business is purchasing and selling timbers . She works at the business for 9-12  hours per day, 6  days per week Naumi currently earns about 90 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase timbers in bulk for business . In the future, she plans to open the same business at new location . Naumi thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase timbers in bulk

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna V. is a 52-year-old mother of five. All her children are now grown-ups; two are in college and two others attend high school. Her husband Marcelino, 48, works as a technician. They live in a small house in Bagong Silang, Caloocan City.

Myrna owns a general store located in their house. She put this up five years ago. Just last year, she ventured into buying and selling cosmetic products and apparel thru the popular direct-selling schemes offered by prominent brands (Personal Collection, Avon, Sarah Lee, etc.) She earns at least P 4,500 a month from these combined business activities.

She has been with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative for a year now. Now on her 6th loan, she has applied for a loan worth P 8,000 with the cooperative to purchase more cosmetic products for her customers. She will also use portions of the funds to purchase additional stocks for her store.

Myrna has been saving a lot of her earnings. She is looking forward to having other businesses soon.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: to purchase more cosmetics for her customers

loans.use: To purchase a stock of palm oil

loans.name: Fatuma's Group

texts.en:
N. Fatuma is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a hard-working and determined lady with a business of selling agricultural produce plus poultry at Samuuka Centre for 30 years. Fatuma says that her business is doing well, except that at times, she is faced with the scarcity of produce to sell because of bad seasons and this affects her cash flow. She is able to earn 80,000/= on average as profit each week and this helps her to save for future developments. She has been successful because of the use of her loans to acquire quality produce as well as because of good customer care.

Fatuma has a dream of becoming a wholesale supplier of agricultural produce so that she could be able to sell more plus educating all her children to the highest level of education. At the moment, Fatuma needs a loan to help recapitalize her business for a steady supply of agricultural products to her customers.

loans.use: Recapitalizing her business for a steady supply of agricultural produce to her customers

loans.name: Angie

texts.en:
Angie G., 41 years old, raises pigs to help augment their family’s income in support to her husband Jaime, a jail officer. They live in Bagong Silang, Caloocan City. They have three children; the eldest is in high school, another attends pre-school, and the youngest is not yet of school -going age.

Angie has been raising pigs in their backyard for three years now. When the pigs are ready for slaughtering, she brings them to the neighborhood butcher. While waiting for her pigs to mature, she finds time to attend to her other business – selling electronic load credits for mobile phones. She liked this business because she doesn’t need to leave the house every time. Angie earns more than P5,000 net per month from her business activities.

She has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative since 2007. She has just finished repaying her previous loans with said cooperative so she has applied for a new loan in the amount of P12,000 to purchase more electronic load credits to retail to her customers.

Angie dreams of having a mobile phone shop in the future.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.name: Contact Group

texts.en:
Contact Group is a group of five borrowers led by Batu G.. She is 45 years old and the single mother of seven children aged 8 to 22 years old with educational levels of 4th through 12th grade. Batu is illiterate due to poverty. She and her family live in Banjour, a newly-built community for poor people who can't afford to buy town lots. It is situated in Virginia, north of Monrovia, the capital of Liberia.

Batu’s business is selling food ingredients. She buys food ingredients wholesale like salt, seasoning, bouillon cubes, onions, tomato paste, etc., and sells retail to the residents of Banjour. She has been running this business for three years and hopes to get into a used car business and become one of the biggest businesswomen in Liberia.

Everyone at Batu's business place sells the same goods and that makes for competition. To counter this, she parcels her goods in bigger quantities and differently from other vendors and she also gives her customers a good approach in order to get more customers.

Batu needs this loan in order to purchaS. new goods to improve her business. She dreams of giving her children a better education to prepare them for the future.

loans.use: To buy new goods to improve her business

loans.name: Fati

texts.en: Fati I. is married and has five dependants. She has no educational background.  Fati sells palm oil, coconut oil and palm kernel oil at Elmina, which she has been doing since 1999. Her husband is a carpenter.  Fati uses her income to support her husband in paying of school fees and utility bills.  Fati will use the loan to purchase more palm oil coconut oil and palm kernel oil for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Fati plans to save to build a house.

loans.use: Fati will use the loan to purchase more palm oil coconut oil and palm kernel oil for sale.
