Bernadeth is 23 years old and she is already married to Richard.  They have a four year old daughter named Andrea Lhei who attends a Day Care Center and she is now pregnant with their second child.  Her husband is busy on his farm located in their village in Minallo, Naguillan, Isabela. Bernadeth has a lot of dreams for her children, which is the reason why she and her husband are working hard to provide the needs of their children.  

Bernadeth is raising hogs as her way of helping her husband earn a living.  She already sold her grown-up hogs and used her profit to purchase piglets.  As a business woman, she wants to have additional capital to become more profitable.  She is now asking for financial assistance from KIVA lenders who could help her become more successful in her business. She now wants to borrow a loan of PHP10,000 to have additional funds to purchase feed and to further increase the number of her hogs. Her business is very beneficial to her family and she hopes that as times passes by, her business will continue to grow.

loans.use: Additional capital for business growth

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Meas S. is a long-time business woman and low-income person. She has been working on the farm since she was single. On her own small farm land, she plants different kinds of crops which she proposes to harvest and sell to a buyer when the crops are mature. Her husband helps work with her in growing their crop. Meas S. has six single children, two of whom are staff workers for industry. She planted her crop two months ago but her crop is not growing well due to lack of fertilizer. Therefore, Meas S. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer to fatten her crop yield. Note: Mrs. Meas S.'s husband appears in the picture.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Saem

texts.en:
Saem L., 50, is married with five children. He lives in Battambong province with his wife (pictured) and children. He is a skillful carpenter who travels from place to place in his province where his customers employ him to work on their houses. He is able to earn an income of approximately US$5 per day to cover his family expenses.

His wife operates a business selling groceries at their home, earning an income of US$3 per day. L. is asking for a loan of US$400 to purchase various kinds of groceries to expand his wife’s business and to stock the store. By doing so, L. hopes that his wife will be able to generate more income to save for future household use.

loans.use: To buy groceries for his wife's store

loans.name: Raymond

texts.en:
Raymond E. is a fisherman. He is a a young father, 26 years old, who does the best he can to be able to provide his family with enough food, clothes and basic needs. He dreams of having a decent house; he also dreams that all his children will grow healthy and respectful just like his parents taught him when he was still a child.

Raymond requested a loan of Php 7,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. He will use the loan to buy fishing equipement to use. Currently, he is repairing an old net but, through the small loan, he will be able to buy a new one. He will also use some of the loan to buy fish from other fishermen to resell. Fishing is a very good business. If his loan is approved, he could start immediately selling fish to the nearby towns and villages.

loans.use: To buy fishing equipment and fish to resell

loans.name: Vis

texts.en: Vis C. is married with 2 young children. She lives with husband (pictured) in Battambong Province. She is involved in a business of selling groceries near a local school, earning approximately an income of US $3 per day. To make living, her husband operates his motor taxi everywhere in the town, earning an income of US $5 per day as a primary source of income for the family. This young couple is seeking to improve the standard of living by starting another business because Chhorvion’s current business does not allow her to generate enough income to make a good living and for the future education of their children. Therefore, she is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase a motorbike attached with a cart to stock meatballs that are ready to be fried for sale.

loans.use: buy a motorbike attach with a cart

loans.name: Maria Paz

texts.en:
Maria Paz is a mother of two children who are both presently studying in high school. Maria Paz is 36 years old, managing her own business of retailing goods in her general store within her community. She has been in this business seven years. Her business serves her by providing her children's allowance in school. Her greatest dream is to successfully send her children through school to finish their studies. 

Her husband is busy with his farming activities. Their net income in their yields is exactly enough for their children's allowances and their other school enrollment fees. But their income is really insufficient; they need an extra source of income to fully support their children's allowances, for them not to experience some difficulty in providing for the needs of their children. She is asking to borrow the amount of 5,000 PHP from Kiva lenders for additional capital to buy more items to sell in her store.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell in her store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Regie

texts.en:
Regie A. is a fisherman and at the same time a seaweed grower in their island. He has four children, with 9 years old as the eldest who inspire him always to pursue more on his seaweed business. He works whole day to take care of the seaweeds. He is doing the best he can to be able to sustain their livelihood because it is where his family depends on for food, clothes and other basic needs.

He requested a loan of Php 7,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc to fund his business. The loan will help a lot to buy more seaweed seedlings since he has expanded the size of his seaweed farm. In that way, he believes that he will be able to have more seaweeds and more income for his family in the future.

loans.use: To buy seaweed seedlings

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap N., 30 and her husband, Mr. Chorn Chea, 33, live on an island on the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married since 2000 and have two sons. All of them are still young. 

Sopheap has been a silk weaver since she was young, a skill she learned from her mother. She also taught her husband to become a silk weaver. They sell their finished products to a middleman, who then in turns them to sell in Phnom Penh market. 

Sopheap doesn’t have enough capital to purchase weaving materials (raw silk and cotton thread), that’s why she is requesting her first loan of $250 to in order to make the purchases.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel is already 31 years old, and she is married to Allan B., who works as a farmer on their own land. They now have two children: Alainebless, three years old, and Alaiza, four months old. They are the couple’s main source of inspiration. Their family lives in Minallo, a village of Naguilian, Isabela.

Maribel has been raising ducks and hogs at the back of their house for two years already. She needs additional working capital to maintain her livestock business. She hopes to avail of a loan of 9,000 PHP from lenders. This amount will be of great help in purchasing feed for her livestock. She hopes that lenders will entrust her with the loan she is trying to obtain. This will make her business more productive.

loans.use: To buy feed for her livestock

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz has been a vegetable vendor for ten years. She sells various kinds of vegetables in their village, and she usually sells them on a house-to-house basis. For the continuous growth of her business, she is now hoping to avail of a loan of 14,000 PHP from Kiva lenders. Her loan request has the potential to benefit not only her business but also her family.  

Luz is 34 years old and married to Charlie, a hog raiser and farmer. They are living in Minallo, Naguilian, Isabela. The couple has three children: Cherry, 22 years old; Lyla, 18 years old; and Charlie, 13 years old. Of the three, Charlie is the only one who’s still studying; her older sisters just finished their secondary education and weren’t able to enter college due to lack of money. She hopes that her retail business will become more productive to be able to meet their daily needs and uplift their poor living condition.

loans.use: Additional capital for the improvement of her business

loans.name: Abita

texts.en:
41-year old Abita H. started her fishing business in Danao, Panglao in 2007.  She has 9 children and her eldest is 23 years old.  Her dream is to make her business become successful and that she can help send her children to school.

She joined in Community Economic Ventures, Inc. on 2007.  This time she’s requesting a loan amounting to Php 16,000.  The loan will be helpful for her to buy materials necessary for fishing.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Fely

texts.en:
With her income in her business, Fely M. allows her to support their family needs. She is 41 years old married and gifted with only child. Fely is engage in business selling of kugon or a kind of roof light material made of dried grass. She is also manages a charcoal making business. Her business is risky because she needs to go in mountains with his husband just to get kugon to sell. In terms of charcoal making she also cuts wood and dried them for some days to make a charcoal. When it totally become charcoal, she sells it in market of Mallig and in their village. 

The couple is dreaming that their child will successfully finish her education and will have a better future. Their tried their best to comply in their responsibility to their child as a good parents. Fely wanted to borrow the amount of Php 6,000 for additional capital for the improvement of her businesses.

loans.use: additional capital for her business

loans.name: Snguon

texts.en: Snguon N., 49, is a local rice farmer who has been working in this sector since 1990. She and her husband grow rice on their own farmland. They also harvest and sell their mature produce around three months after they began planting. From this business, they can generate an income of around $3 USD per day. This humble couple has three single children and one married child. One of their daughters has been tailoring from home for years, but she still requires more materials to support her service. Snguon N. is taking out her loan to buy a machine which will enable her daughter to sew clothes.

loans.use: To buy a machine which will enable her daughter to sew clothes

loans.name: Genara

texts.en:
A buy-and-sell business is the kind of business Genara A. manages. She’s 52 years old, from Danao, Panglao, and has 7 children. She has been in this business since 1987, and she wishes that her business would go well.

She would like to borrow the amount of 13,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to have additional capital for her business. It would help her a lot in solving her problems in financing.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Srun

texts.en: Srun S. is 36 years old and resides with her husband in the Kampong Cham province. She works in a grocery store, making approximately US$1.50 each day. She also raises pigs and chickens for her additional income. Her husband is a farmer who typically makes about US$3 per day. He grows rice, fruit and vegetables. This couple has two school-aged children. Srun would like to take out a loan of US$500 to make two investments. She uses US$250 to rebuild her grocery store and the leftover is used to raise more chickens.

loans.use: Rebuild grocery store and raise chickens.

loans.name: Amy

texts.en:
Amy T. is an industrious housewife of Jaime T. of Brgy. Roxas, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is now 55 years old having two children namely, Alvin T. and Dona Mae T.. They are now in tertiary and secondary education respectively. With their interest to give them a better future, they are very supportive to their financial and moral needs. Despite our economic crisis, they are striving hard to earn income for their daily living.
	Farming is their common source of living, they cultivates their parcel of land by planting rice and some vegetables twice a year. Since harvesting takes a long time, Amy engaged in fish vending in their village. She started it with a small capital earning a net income of P 350.00 per day. Due to cost of commodities and educational expenses, she needs to earn a higher to meet their daily living and finance the education of their children. In this regard, she applied for a loan in a Microfinance organization and applied an amount of Php 10,000.00 to further develop her capital to buy more kinds of fish to sell and for the improvement of her business. She is hoping that at the back of their patience and sacrifices there is a valley of success. As they believe that, “Success is always at the end of every sacrifices”.

loans.use: additional capital to buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
To have a successful life is the dream of Rosalinda A.. At 43 years old, she has seven children and really wants to send all her children to school.

Rosalinda runs a fishing business in Danao, Panglao. She started this business way back in 1990. In 2007, she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. because it provides good benefits and leads the members to do well.

Now, Rosalinda is requesting a loan of Php 12,000 to help finance her business by buying fishing equipment.

loans.use: To buy fishing equipment

loans.name: Nan

texts.en: Nan S., 33, is married and lives in the Kampong Cham province with her husband and two young children. To earn a living, she has been selling rice noodle in the community to earn a living and is able to make about US$1.60 every day. Her husband operates a grocery store from home, earning approximately US$2 each day. Due to the buying demand is increasing, Mrs. Nan is asking for a loan of US$400 her husband needs to expand grocery’s inventory.

loans.use: To expand grocery’s inventory.

loans.name: Justina

texts.en:
Justina C. has been managing a sari-sari store since June 2005 in Danao, Panglao.  With 7 children, she wants them to finish their studies.  She’s now 49 years old and would like to make her business be sustained.

She joins Community Economic Ventures, Inc. requesting a loan of Php 12,000 to buy groceries for her sari-sari store.  Joining CEVI helps her business grow and provide the needs for her family.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Catalino

texts.en:
Catalino is a good father to his three children: Evanghelyo, Priscila, and his youngest, Sonia. The children are already married.

Catalino has been separated from his wife for almost thirteen years. He started all over again when he met a woman who completes his life: his second wife. They are living harmoniously and happily residing beside his son's house at San Francisco, Alicia.

Catalino has been a tricycle operator and driver for almost ten years, earning a daily net income of PHP 200. He plans to borrow PHP 5,000 from lenders for the repair and maintenance of his motorcycle. He wants to increase his income and reach a bountiful life with full blessings.

loans.use: To repair and maintain his motorcycle

loans.name: Cerina

texts.en:
58-year old Cerina M. has a sari-sari store in Danao, Panglao.  She has 5 children, the eldest is 33 years old.  Since 1987 this is the kind of business she has been managing.

She likes the program in Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and joined last 2007.  Now she’s asking for a loan of Php 10,000 to buy additional supplies for her sari-sari store.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Bin

texts.en: Bin P. was born in 1962, a married woman and is the mother blessed with eight children. Five of them are married and live independently, while other three live in home and go to school. Bin P. sells some vegetables and groceries in the local market, as another source of income comes from she provides a karaoke service for singing. She has an attractive place which she uses for her service. While her husband‘s name is Thorn Buthoeun, (he appears in the picture here) works with her in the business. Bin P. will be used her first loan to decorate her karaoke room in order to attract more customer.

loans.use: To decorate her karaoke room in order to attract more customer

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
“ If there’s a will, there’s a way”  is the guiding principle of Monica L., a mother living in Brgy. Roxas, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. High school was her highest educational attainment, as her parents could not afford to finance her college education. Despite of it, she found a job and helped her parents  earn a living. When she is 24, she married Julio L. and they are blessed with two children whom they called Julius L. and Jesica L.. Both of them are now in secondary school. They want that their children to finish a degree so that they will someday find good jobs and have a bright future. In this regard, this couple is striving hard to earn income to satisfy their needs and finance their childrens education. 

Her husband is one of the farmers in Brgy. He cultivates their farm by planting rice and variety of vegetables twice a year while Monica engages in selling soft drinks and ice in their village. She will use the loan that she has requested from one of the Microfinance organization, as capital in acquiring her products. Every week, she is able to sold 10-15 cases of soft drinks, earning a net income of Php 600.00 which she uses to acquire their daily needs, finance the school fees of their children, and pay her weekly loan amortization. Due to the high cost of commodities and school expenditures, she needs to earn more income to satisfy and meet their needs. Therefore, she is requesting a loan amount of Php 8,000.00 to strengthen her capital in the improvement of her business. With the loan amount, she would able to purchase more soft drinks to sell. She hopes that with her patience and sacrifices, she can improve her business and support the studies of their children.

loans.use: additional capital to purchase more soft drinks

loans.name: Kosal Iv’S Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Kosal I. (on the right of the picture) was selected to be a group leader for a loan from Maxima. In the group are two families including her. All the group's members are living on an island in Mekong River approximately 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

1-Mrs. Kosal I., 47, is widow with two sons. One of her sons is an electrician and another one weaves silk at home. She is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase silk materials for continuing her weaving business.

2-Mrs. Sok-heng P., 19, is a silk weaver, has been married Mr. Yeun Yun, 28, is a silk weaver since 2008. The young couple has no children yet. Sok-heng is also requesting a loan of $300 to purchase silk materials for continuing her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokha B., 55, and her husband, Mr. Un Choen, 57, have been married since 1975 and have 6 children-1 son and 5 daughters. Three of them are married and live outside the family home, and the other three are silk weavers. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Sokha has is a silk weaver, but she transferred her loom to her daughters. Her husband is a farmer. Sokha has asked for a loan from Kiva through Maxima one time already. She now is requesting anther loan again of $350 to purchase silk materials for her daughters to continue weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her daughters to continue weaving businesses.

loans.name: Touch

texts.en: Touch M., 36, has one young child and lives in the Kampong Cham province with her husband, Sun Phal. They work together selling utensils and they make around US$5 each day. They have their parents to support as well in their household. Touch M. is asking for a loan of US$900 to purchase more utensils to sell. They believe that with the loan, the expansion of their business will bring about an increased income and a higher standard of living.

loans.use: Buy utensils.

loans.name: San

texts.en: San S., 29, has three children and lives in the Kampong Cham province with her husband, Hea Siem. Since 2000, she has been raising pigs to earn a living and is able to make US$1.50 of profit every day, while her husband makes US$6.60 each day as a blacksmith. Two of the children are in school and one is too young to attend. San S. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 she needs to purchase farmland. She believes that with the loan, the expansion of her business will bring about an increased income and a higher standard of living.

loans.use: To buy farmland.

loans.name: Vuthy

texts.en:
Miss. Vuthy S., age 30, is single and has three brothers and a sister. She lives with her parents on an island in Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Vuthy has been a silk weaver since she was 13 years old, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in the Phnom Penh market or other places. Vuthy is asking for a loan of $200 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Soun

texts.en: Soun V., 36, lives with her three children and husband in Kampong Cham province. She is a farmer who typically makes about US$1 every day. Her husband has operated a horse cart business since 2004 and is able to make US$6 per day. Soun has an idea to make more money to support her family. She would like to take out a loan of US$700 to purchase rice and bean in bulk with a special wholesale discount and then resell it at the market.

loans.use: To purchase rice and beans to resell.

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en:
Mr. Saroeun P., age 43, (pictured with his wife) and his wife, Mrs. Saren Cheum, age 26, were married in 1999 and have two sons. One of them studies in the local school but, unfortunately, the other one died. The family lives along National Road Number One about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Saroeun has been a traditional musician for two years while his wife has been selling fruit for four years. Saroeun is asking for his first loan of $500 to provide business capital for his wife to enable her to purchase fruit on contract for resale.

loans.use: To use as capital for his wife's business

loans.name: Pon

texts.en: Pon C., 40, is married and lives with her husband in the Kampong Cham province. She sells clothes at the local market to earn a living and is able to make about US$6 per day. Her husband is a farmer who typically makes US$4 each day. He also raises pigs and chickens. This couple is also supported by two of the children who are garment worker and one other sell CDs and VCDs from home. Pon C. is asking for a loan of US$1000 she needs to expand her clothes’ inventory.

loans.use: To expand her clothes’ inventory.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mrs. Mom S., 52 and her husband, Mr. Bunthol Teang, 56, live on an island on the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married since 1975 and have 5 children-2 sons and 3 daughters. Two of them weave silk at home, one is a security guard, one is a goldsmith and another one is studies in local school.  

Mom has been a silk weaver for 20 years, while her husband has been a policeman for 30 years. She is requesting a loan of $300 in order to purchase silk materials for her weaving businesses.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving businesses.

loans.name: Pharoth

texts.en:
Mrs. Pharoth U., 32, and her husband, Mr. Sambath Chea, 38, have been married since 1990 but have no children yet. The couple live along National Road Number One approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. Pharoth is shown in the photo with her mother.

Pharoth has been a garment factory worker for about ten years, while her husband has been a construction worker for about twenty years. Pharoth is able to earn about $80 a month and her husband is able to earn 20,000 riel (about $5) per day. 

The couple is in the process of building a new house to live in, but the house isn’t finished yet. So Pharoth is asking for a loan of $1,000 in order to finish it.

loans.use: To finish building her house

loans.name: Riel

texts.en:
Mr. Riel S., 41, is a Civil Service officer for the Ministry of Fisheries. He is married to Em Rina, age 41, a local teacher. The couple has six children: four are single and two are married and live separately.

The family cultivates a rice crop. The rice-farming season is coming and Riel S. would like a loan from Kiva. He will use the loan to hire a laborer to plow his farmland and to purchase farming materials such as seed, fertilizer and a pump for irrigation.

loans.use: To hire a laborer to plow his farmland and to buy items needed on his farm

loans.name: Yorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Yorn Pon, 50, is a widow with three sons and three daughters. Three of them are married and live outside the family home. Besides her children, she also has her old mother living with her. The family lives along National Road Number One about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Yorn has been a farmer for more than 30 years. She grows papayas, bananas, tomatoes, etc. She sells her products to a middleman who comes to buy them at her home. Farming is the main source of income for supporting Yorn’s family so she is requesting a loan of $1,000 in order to raise capital for continuing her farming business.

loans.use: To use for farming

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty S. is from the village of Rizal, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old. Betty is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Betty owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling vegetables in the local community. Betty has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2009, Betty joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Betty has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for selling vegetables. Betty is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the second loan taken out by Betty from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
Lorena is 52 years old and a business woman from the village of San Vicente, Quirino, Isabela. She is married to Julito and they have two children: Ednalyn and Manuel who are both married. 

Lorena  used to engaged in a retailing business.  However, due to lack of capital, it did not survive so she was forced to close it since she cannot meet the demands of her customers.  

She then decided to venture into the hog raising business which is located in their back yard.  With the small capital from her store, she used it to purchased a few hogs.  She hopes to increase her hogs but she needs more capital.  She is hoping that KIVA lenders will give her the chance to make her business productive by lending her a loan of PHP8,000.00.  This will be of great help in making her business profitable.

loans.use: Additional capital to purchase more hogs

loans.name: Ruel

texts.en:
“Victory is always possible to a person who never stops fighting,” says Ruel as he shares his guiding principle in life. Ruel is 21 years old and resides in the village of San Vicente, Quirino, Isabela. He is still single and is engaged in a small business. He still lives with his parents and is proud that he is able to assist his parents with their daily needs.  

Ruel is a vendor of frozen foods in his village. Aside from this, he also sells electronic load for additional income.  He aspires to be more progressive in his business and to be able to have another source of livelihood in their village. For this reason, he is requesting a loan amounting to 8,000 Philippine pesos that he can use for business growth. He is very determined to achieve his dreams; that is the reason why he gives his full attention to his business.

loans.use: Additional capital to grow his business

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita M., a 54-year-old single mother of one adult-aged child, is from the village of Poblacion, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. To make a living, Clarita owns and operates a specialized "sari-sari" retail store whose main source of income comes from selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Clarita has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Clarita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC that was used to purchase additional products to sell, Clarita is now requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be her fourth from GDMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase used clothes in bulk

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma is a hog raise for three years.  Her need for financial assistance encouraged her to request for financial assistance from  the KIVA lenders to support her hog raising business. She would like to borrow a loan of PHP5,000. She hopes that her loan will be granted because it will be of so much help for the growth of her business. 

Vilma is 41 years old and a mother of five. Her children are still young and in order to meet their growing needs, she is working patiently with her business to earn a living.

loans.use: Additional capital for the growth of her hog raising business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase rice in bulk

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida H. manages a barbeque business in Danao, Panglao. Through this kind of business, she has been able to sustain her family and pay her debts. She’s 34 years old and the eldest of her 5 children is 12 years old.

She’s requesting a loan of Php 7,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to have additional capital for her business. She will be able to buy materials for her business.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Carlosa

texts.en:
Carlosa L. is a mother of 3 children. She has a barbeque business in Danao, Panglao. She wishes to make her business grow and overcome the crisis in life. She started this kind of business in 2008.

In 2007, she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. because of the good program it has. She’s now requesting a loan of Php 6,000 to help finance her business.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Wilson's Group

texts.en:
Wilson M. is 37 years old and the leader of his group in Bushenyi. He is married with three children, who are all currently enrolled in school. Wilson has been farming his whole life and has been operating his own banana plantation for 20 years. He would like to use the loan to generally improve the conditions of his plantation, thereby increasing crop yields.

Wilson believes that larger harvests will allow him to begin supplying organizations and big towns with bananas. He hopes that with his continued hard work, one day he will be able to send all of his kids to university.

loans.use: Improvements to Banana Plantation

loans.name: Cornelio

texts.en:
Cornelio E. is a tricycle (three-wheeled transport) driver in Banga, South Cotabato. He is 39 years old with 3 children. He owns a motorcycle which is his main source of income. He also has 1 sow.

He would like to request a loan of Php 8000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to buy motorcycle parts and a pig. The loan will be helpful for him to sustain his business and provide the basic needs of his family.

loans.use: motorcycle parts and a pig

loans.name: Lourng

texts.en:
Lourng P. is 34 years old and sells fruit in Kampong Cham province. Her business has been around for about four years and she makes US$5 every day, while her husband is a policeman and is able to make US$3 each day.

Selling fruit has been a difficult business as there is high inflation and weather conditions have not been conducive to a good growing season. She is asking for a loan of US$ 1000 to reinvest into her own fruit business, increasing her stock of fruit to sell. She sees this investment as an opportunity that will be able to increase her daily income.

loans.use: Reinvest in her fruit business

loans.name: Sao

texts.en:
Sao S., 26 years old and a married man, is also a father caring for two young kids. He owns a handicraft business. He and his wife weave bamboo basket out of their home. They also save a hundred sets of baskets before selling them.

Sao S. owns a horse-cart which he uses to pick up his products to sell. Usually, he needs to spend time selling his products for a few days or a week. Beside this work, Sao S. has a farming business during the approaching annual farming season.

Sao S. requests a loan to buy a plot of farmland in good location for farming. He will use this new land for cultivating rice.

loans.use: to buy a plot of farmland in a good location for farming

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza, 31 years of age is married to Jose B., they have three children namely; Judy Ann- 15 years of age, 4th year high school student, followed by Jessie James- 13 years old, 1st year high school student, and their youngest is Joshua- 11 years of age, grade five student. They are presently residing at Barangay Pulo San Francisco, Isabela, 12 kilometers away from the national highway.

 She manages a food vending business for almost two years, particularly she sells rice cakes at public market of Cauayan City, aside from that she is also a direct seller of laundry products. Her weekly net income is minimum of PHP 750.00, and maximum of PHP 900.00, she applied a loan amount of PHP 15,000.00 for her additional capital to buy more selling products. She hopes that lenders will grant her loan as much as possible in order to attain her income in supporting her family needs. She believed that "no matter how hard you try to become successful, if you don't know how to build your self- esteem, you will lose what you have".

loans.use: Additional capital in her vending business

loans.name: Say

texts.en:
Say T. is 58 years old and resides in Kampong Cham province with her husband and four of her children. She works together with her husband as farmers who are able to make approximately US$4 every day. This couple is also supported by some of the children who raise ducks from home. This business is allows them to make US$12 in revenue each day.

Say T. is asking for a loan of US$ 750 to purchase more ducks to breed. (Say's son is pictured.)

loans.use: Raise ducks.

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Kim L., 43, is a widow with two school-aged children. Living in the Kampong Cham, she typically makes about US$7.50 per day by selling porridge in the morning and dessert in the evening. However, she still looks after her disable mother. To earn more money, she needs a loan from CREDIT of US$1000 to make a new investment. She would use this loan to raise cows for sale.

loans.use: Raise cows.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok S. is 26 years old and lives with her husband in the Kampong Cham province. She owns a food stand in front of local market. On average, she is able to make a profit of US$1.80 each day. Her husband, Kong Veng, 41, pictured here with his daughter, is a motor-taxi driver. He typically makes US$4 every day. Sok S. is asking for a loan of US$250 her husband needs to repair the moto.

loans.use: repair the moto.

loans.name: Virgilio

texts.en:
34-year old tricycle driver Virgilio G. raised 3 pigs, and earns Php 400-1000 daily in his sari-sari store in Banga, South Cotabato.  In 2004 he started this kind of business in order to provide the basic needs of his family and education for his 2 children.

He joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and would like to request a loan amount of Php 15,000.  This loan would be helpful to finance his business with a lower interest rate.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Kim Y., 49, is married and lives with six of her children in the Kampong Cham province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about US$2 each day and are supported by three children working in the garment factory. Kim’s husband also raises chickens to have an additional income to help the standard of living. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Kim Y. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$1200 to purchase fertilizer and feed for chickens. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and feed for chickens.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma P. is from the village of Seti, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old. Emma is married and has 2 children. To make a living, Emma owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting coconuts for sale. Emma has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Emma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emma is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the first loan taken out by Emma from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Keit

texts.en: Keit S., 31, is a farmer who lives with her husband and four of her children. Living in the Kampong Cham, she typically makes US$2 every day. Her husband, pictured here, is a local doctor. He sells medicines and treats an illness from house to house. He earns approximately US$6 each day. Keit S. is asking for a loan of US$1000 her husband needs to purchase medicines and medical equipments.

loans.use: Buy medicines

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario C. manages a 1 hectare rice field in Banga, South Cotabato.  She is 39 years old with 5 children.  The eldest of her children is still 17 years old.  She also raised 3 pigs as another source of income for her family.

January 2007, she joins Community Economic Ventures, Inc. in order to have a loan with a lower interest rate.  She's now requesting a loan of Php 15,000 to help finance her existing business.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Narcisa

texts.en:
Narcisa, 42 years old, is from the village of Santa Isabel Norte, Ilagan, Isabela. She is married to Ronilo Montales who is working hard in their own farm. They have four children, of whom two are still studying. Their eldest Jenilyn is now 20 years old and already married. Second is Raphie, 19 years old, a high school graduate; he is now helping his father in the farm. Next is Riezel Grace, 16 years old, she is presently studying as a first year college student . Rona Jean, their youngest, is now 14 years old and she is presently a third year student in secondary school.

Narcisa has been selling vinegar and soy sauce in their village. She purchases vinegar and soy sauce in huge containers and retails it by dividing or pouring it into small bottles. From this business, Narcisa is generating a net income of PHP 5,000 monthly which is of great help in providing the needs of their family.

Narcisa is planning to re-open her general store but she has insufficient capital to purchase various commodities. For this reason, she is requestingl a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 to be used as additional starting capital for her retail business. She hopes that with the help of lenders, she will be able to pursue her retail business to provide a better living for her family. She hopes that her loan will be approved.

loans.use: additional capital to pursue her retail business

loans.name: Felicisima

texts.en:
58-year old Felicisima F. manages a sari-sari store in Banga, South Cotabato.  She owns 2 motorcycles and raised 2 pigs as additional sources of income.  She has 5 children, the eldest is already 36 years old.  The daily needs of her family are met because of her business.

Now she still needs an additional capital to help finance her existing business.  She would like to request a loan of Php 10000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc.  This will help her in financing her business.

loans.use: Financing

loans.name: Jelly

texts.en:
Jelly Q. is from the village of Villalin, Pana-on Misamis Occidental. She is 41 years old. Jelly is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Jelly owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling personal products such as earrings, bracelets, and necklaces in the local community. Jelly is just starting this business and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Jelly joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jelly has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Jelly is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Jelly from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en: Sorn E., 31, is a modest villager living in Kampong Chhnang Province. She currently lives with her older mother who stays at home to care for housework. She was married, but divorced her husband and has no a child. To earn a living, Sorn E. has owned small handicraft business as a bamboo basket weaver. She makes basket thE. and sells to her buyer in bulk for a profit. Sorn E. faces difficulty to weave baskets due to the weaving place is too small. Therefore, she is applying for a loan to accumulate a larger size of her weaving place.

loans.use: To accumulate a larger size of her weaving place

loans.name: Genedina

texts.en:
Genedina is 42 years of age and is married to Dominador S., who works as a farmer. They have five loving children, namely: Julie Ann - 21 years of age, a cashier in a restaurant; Mary Jane - 19 years of age, at college level; Arnel - 18 years of age, a 4th year high school student; Sheryl Ann - 14 years of age, an out-of-school youth; and Mary Ann - 4 years of age. They live happily together at Pulo, San Francisco, Cauayan City, a rural and plain area. Their house is near San Francisco Elementary School, and in front of the Roman Catholic church.

Genedina has managed the vending of fruits and vegetables in their village for almost eighteen years and her daily net income is PHP 400. She wants to obtain a loan of PHP 8,000 from lenders as additional working capital for her business since she wants to buy additional products to sell.

Genedina wants to maintain her small business in a productive way in order to help her family’s finances.

loans.use: To buy additional products to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Kiden

texts.en:
Kiden A. is currently in the business of selling cooking oil and onions and is requesting a loan to purchase tomatoes and apples to sell. Kiden is 20 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has 1 child and her child does not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase tomatoes and apples to sell
